what is a merism?
a Merism (from Greek μέρεις, meres "part" or "division") in grammar and rhetoric refers to the division of an extended discourse into parts that are roughly equal. The term was originally used by Aristotle for his divisions of speeches he heard delivered at public ceremonies; it is also sometimes called a meristic arrangement.[1]
